datasetVersion.termsOfAccess:
We are accepting proposals for our 2018 Secondary Data Use Grant starting February 20, 2018. This grant provides $5,000 to successful applicants to undertake research using data in SAGE. The term of the grant is 12 months. The grant offers an excellent opportunity for trainees and new researchers to work with existing birth cohort and survey data. Deadline for applications is April 27, 2018 at 4:00 PM MST.

https://policywise.com/initiatives/sage/secondary-data-use-grant/

No special access conditions or procedures beyond the standard SAGE data access protocol. See: https://policywise.com/initiatives/sage/accessing-data/

fields.value: What Albertans Know About Youth Mental Health 2010 Survey

dsDescriptionValue.value:
Mental disorders are the most common cause of disability for youth; the prevalence of child and adolescent mental disorders is nearly 20%. Despite this, 33% of Canadians believe that mental health problems are rare, and 42% of Canadians would not want to reveal that they had a mental illness. The What Albertans Know About Youth Mental Health 2010 Survey is a computer-assisted telephone survey of Alberta adults conducted in 2010 by the Population Research Lab as part of the 2010 Alberta Survey (doi:10.7939/DVN/10008). Questions commissioned by PolicyWise for Children & Families (formerly the Alberta Centre for Child, Family and Community Research) aimed to better understand public knowledge and attitudes towards youth and mental health in the hopes of informing strategies to improve mental health literacy.

These metadata can also be found on SAGE's searchable metadata website:
http://sagemetadata.policywise.com/nada/index.php/catalog/8

producerAffiliation.value: Department of Sociology, University of Alberta

value: Metcalf A, Crockett C, Salegio J, Tough S. What Albertans know about youth mental health. 2011. Prepared for the Alberta Centre for Child, Family and Community Research

otherGeographicCoverage.value: Calgary, Alberta; Edmonton, Alberta; Rest of Alberta

value: Individuals over 18 years of age whose residence can be reached by random direct-dialing

fields.value: Used a Random-Digit Dialling (RDD) approach to ensure that respondents had an equal chance to be contacted whether or not their household was listed in a telephone directory. Gender ratio was maintained (1:1). Minimum of 400 participants from Calgary, 400 from Edmonton, and the balance from rest of Alberta
Overarching survey (Alberta Survey 2010) took, on average, 40 minutes to complete (excluding introductory and screening questions)
'wtx' used to weight responses against Statistics Canada population estimates

Automatic routing of questions and built-in checks for inconsistencies and out-of-range codes. The data were coded, wild codes and discrepant values were eliminated, consistency checks were conducted. In addition, 10% of respondents were randomly selected and re-contacted for interviewing validation
